detaileddescription.para: Should be called in the constructor, and passed the desired parent state. This cannot be done at state declaration (from the compiler's point of view), because of the way templating works (I think).

memberdef.name: RCPPSW_HFSM_ENTRY_DECLARE
memberdef.initializer: public: \ void EN_##entry_name(const event_data*); \ \ private: \ rcppsw::patterns::fsm:: \ state_entry_action1<FSM, event_data, &FSM::EN_##entry_name> \ entry_name

detaileddescription.para: Declare a state in the current HFSM.

The entry handler function MUST be public in order for templating to work. Apparently when dealing with non-type template arguments, any argument passed that does not EXACTLY match the one in the template will cause a compilation error if the function is protected (i.e. accessible in derived classes). The solution: make it public. Not the best, because it exposes the inner workings of the state machine, but anyone who is using this class should only be manipulating it through the macros anyway.
Same as RCPPSW_HFSM_ENTRY_DECLARE(), but with no data.
Declare a entry callback in the current HFSM to be inherited from a parent HFSM.
This can be private because it is just a member variable.
Same as RCPPSW_HFSM_ENTRY_INHERIT(), but with no data.
Declare an exit callback in the current HFSM.
Declare an exit callback in the current HFSM to be inherited from a parent HFSM.
This can be private because it is just a member variable.

memberdef.name: RCPPSW_HFSM_STATE_DECLARE
memberdef.initializer: public: \ int ST_##state_name(event_data*); \ \ private: \ rcppsw::patterns::fsm:: \ hfsm_state_action1<FSM, event_data, &FSM::ST_##state_name> \ state_name

detaileddescription.para: Declare a state in the current HFSM.

The state handler function MUST be public in order for hfsm_state_action1 templating to work. Apparently when dealing with non-type template arguments, any argument passed that does not EXACTLY match the one in the template will cause a compilation error if the function is protected (i.e. accessible in derived classes). The solution: make it public. Not the best, because it exposes the inner workings of the state machine, but anyone who is using this class should only be manipulating it through the macros anyway.
Same as RCPPSW_HFSM_STATE_DECLARE(), but with no data.
Declare a state in the current HFSM to be inherited from a parent HFSM.
This can be private because it is just a member variable.
Same as RCPPSW_HFSM_STATE_INHERIT(), but with no data.
